SENT.plain: A young Caucasian woman developed bilateral deep vein thromboses (DVT) while taking the oral contraceptive (OC) in 1984
After a 9-month period of longterm anticoagulation therapy with warfarin, she experienced recurrent DVT 2 weeks following discontinuation of anticoagulation
She was then maintained with warfarin for the following 6 years
Elevated antibodies to cardiolipin (IgG aCL) were first detected in 1988
In 1990, warfarin was switched to aspirin and low molecular weight heparin as she wished to become pregnant
At 24 weeks she developed eclampsia and labor was induced
During the first postpartum week she experienced loin pain, associated with rapidly rising creatinine levels and features of a nephrotic syndrome
An abdominal ultrasound showed bilateral renal vein thrombosis with enlarged kidneys
She was treated with continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis (CAPD) for 4 months and her renal function is now recovering
Our patient is another example of the primary antiphospholipid syndrome
